title: Examples of presentations
text:
Here we can add links to presentations.
For now you can access the presentation by adjusting the URL below with your details
https://YOUR-GITHUB-ACCOUNT.github.io/NAME-OF-YOUR-GIT-REPO/tab-presentation/presentation1/presentation-example.html
Simply change my capitalized text for your: i) your github username
ii) the name of your github repo then copy the URL and paste it to visit the webpage.
The adjusted URL above should take you to an example of a simple Quarto presentation.

title: Load necessary libraries
text:
Load necessary libraries
library(tibble) library(dplyr) library(lubridate)


Create a codebook for the questionnaire
codebook <- tibble( variable_name = c(“age_group”, “chatbot_usage”, “primary_purpose”, “satisfaction”, “improvements”), question = c( “What is your age group?”, “How often do you interact with AI chatbots?”, “What is the primary purpose for using AI chatbots?”, “How satisfied are you with the chatbot experience?”, “What improvements would you suggest?” ) )


Generate a synthetic dataset
set.seed(123) synthetic_data <- tibble( age_group = sample(c(“Under 18”, “18-24”, “25-34”, “35-44”, “45-54”, “55-64”, “65+”), 200, replace = TRUE), chatbot_usage = sample(c(“Daily”, “Weekly”, “Monthly”, “Rarely”, “Never”), 200, replace = TRUE), primary_purpose = sample(c(“Customer Service”, “Learning”, “Entertainment”, “Productivity”, “Other”), 200, replace = TRUE), satisfaction = sample(1:5, 200, replace = TRUE), # 1 = Very Dissatisfied, 5 = Very Satisfied improvements = sample(c(“Faster Responses”, “Better Understanding”, “More Personalization”, “None”), 200, replace = TRUE) )


Define the start and end datetime
start_datetime <- ymd_hms(“2025-01-01T00:00:00Z”) end_datetime <- ymd_hms(“2025-12-31T23:59:59Z”)


Calculate the total number of seconds in the one-year interval
total_seconds <- as.numeric(difftime(end_datetime, start_datetime, units = “secs”))


Add a user_id and random timestamp
synthetic_data <- synthetic_data %>% rowid_to_column(var = “user_id”) %>% mutate( user_id = paste0(“id_”, user_id), timestamp = start_datetime + seconds(runif(n(), min = 0, max = total_seconds)) )


Save the dataset to a CSV file
write.csv(synthetic_data, “synthetic_survey_data.csv”, row.names = FALSE)


Display the first few rows
print(head(synthetic_data))


Print the codebook
print(codebook)

title: Course overview
text:
What this course is about


1. Workflow




2. Communicating data

title: Course overview
text:
What is a Dashboard?

Dashboards provide a visual display of the most important information needed to achieve one or more objectives.
They consolidate and arrange information on a single screen.

Key Characteristics of Effective Dashboards

Clarity: Information should be easy to read and interpret.
Accuracy: Data must be accurate and up-to-date.
Relevance: Content should align with user goals and needs.

title: Course overview
text:
The Role of Visual Design

Minimize distractions and unnecessary elements.
Use consistent layouts and formatting.
Apply thoughtful use of color and typography.

Best Practices for Dashboard Design

Avoid clutter: Only display essential information.
Prioritize data: Highlight key metrics and KPIs.
Use visual hierarchy: Direct the viewer’s focus to the most important elements.

title: Course overview
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid

Overloading the user with too much data.
Using overly complex or inconsistent designs.
Neglecting the importance of user testing.

What You Shoud Do

Focus on the needs and goals of the dashboard’s end-users.
Iteratively test and refine designs to improve usability.

title: Course overview
text:
Summary

Dashboards are powerful tools for decision-making.
Effective dashboards balance clarity, relevance, and visual appeal.
Avoid common pitfalls by focusing on user needs and testing designs.
